FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_3.Description:
Prevention Program Description:

This facility has management systems to ensure compliance with all the elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation (29 CFR 1910.119):  



Process Hazard, Technology and Equipment Information - 1910.119(d)(1),(2) and (3)

Process Hazard Analysis - 1910.119(e)

Operating Procedures - 1910.119(f)]

Training - 1910.119(g) 

Mechanical Integrity - 1910.119(j)

Quality Assurance - 1910.119(j)(6)

Management of Change - 1910.119(l)

Pre-startup Reviews - 1910.119(i)

Compliance Audits - 1910.119(o)

Incident Investigation - 1910.119(m)

Employee Participation - 1910.119(c)

Hot Work Permit -1910.119(k)

Contractors - 1910.119(h)

Emergency Planning and Response - 1910.119(n)

Trade Secrets - 1910.119(p)



In addition there is a system for Management of Change-Personnel that is required (above and beyond OSHA's PSM requirements) by Chemours Engineering Standard S21A.  This system ensures that a sufficient level of experience is retained in each operating area by controlling personnel turnover.



The Plant Manager has ultimate responsibility for compliance with PSM and all applicable environmental (EPA) regulations.  This responsibility is shared by the Operations line organization; the Operations line organization are people responsible for the operation of each specific area of the plant.  



The Plant Manager also designates a site Process Safety Management leader who oversees the update of management systems for each of the elements of PSM, and reviews the performance of each element in consultation with the element leader designated to manage each element.  The site PSM Leader and the element leaders comprise the site PSM Committee.  The PSM Committee is a subcommitte of the site's Central Safety, Health and Environmental Committee.  Performance of each element is reviewed at least once per year, and on an as-needed basis.  



The organizational structure and the lines of authority at the DeLisle Plant for PSM/RMP implementation and compliance are as follows:

PLANT MANAGER

  Operations Manager

    Area Manager - Reaction, Coke and Ore and Chlorine Operations

    Area Manager - Purification and Oxidation Operations

    Area Manager - RPOE Maintenance

    Area Manager - Environmental Operations

    Area Manager - Finishing Operations

    Area Manager - Finishing Maintenance

    Area Manager - Power Operations

    Area Manager - Packing Operations

    Area Manager - PD/Power & Shift Maintenance

    Area Manager - Supply Chain - Warehouse

    Area Manager - Supply Chain - Raw Materials & Quality Control Lab



Engineering Manager

  Contract Administrators (2)

  Project Engineers



Unit Manager - Human Resources

Unit Manager - Environmental, Health, Safety (EHS)

  PSM Leader / Sr. Environmental Consultant

  Environmental Consultants (2)

  Area Manager - Safety

    Process Safety Clerk    

    Occupational Health Specialist

  

Unit Manager Research and Development for RPOE Unit

Unit Manager Research and Development for FPD Unit

Senior Public & Community Affairs Specialist

Facility Security Officer



The EHS Unit Manager is responsible for ensuring that the facility has effective PSM/RMP procedures.  The site PSM leader reports to the EHS Unit Manager.

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Harrison Co. Local Emerg. Plng Comm

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Chemours Company and the DeLisle Plant have a written Environmental, Health and Safety Policy that seeks to drive environmental responsibility by complying with all environmental laws and regulations and our voluntary commitments.  We actively look for ways to reduce or environmental footprint through pollution prevention, waste reduction, and conservation of energy resources.  Environmental sustainability is embedded in our purpose, culture, planning and training.  We foster a culture of collaboration, inclusion and engagement where we value the unique perspectives of all stakeholders to meet or exceed the needs of our stakeholders and society. 



The Chemours Company and the DeLisle Plant are members of the American Chemistry Council and comply with the Responsible Care code of management practices.  Chemours and the DeLisle Plant are also ISO14001 certified.  



The Chemours Plant at DeLisle, Mississippi is located on the north shore of the Bay of St. Louis about 15 miles west of Gulfport, Mississippi.  The plant is located on a 2,417-acre site; however, only about 348 acres are developed.  We manufacture a single product, titanium dioxide (TiO2), under the trade name TiPure(TM).  Titanium dioxide is manufactured via the chloride-ilmenite process in which naturally-occurring ilmenite ore is directly chlorinated to titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4); the TiCl4 is subsequently re-oxidized to refined TiO2.  The RMP covered chemicals we handle are detailed in the following:



    CHEMICAL                              USE AT DELISLE

    Chlorine                              Produce Titanium Tetrachloride

    Titanium Tetrachloride                Intermediate used in the manufacture of TiO2





The success of the site's PSM program can be gauged by the fact that in the past five (5) years, there have been no accidental releases that resulted in OSHA recordable injuries or off-site shelter-in-place notifications or evacuations of neighbors. In order to drive continuous imp

rovement, there has been increased emphasis to report and investigate minor incidents.  



In addition to having a successful PSM program, the site has effective Emergency Response systems.  The procedures that comprise DeLisle's emergency response program are contained in the site Emergency Procedures Manual. The Plant has held coordinated drills with community first responders and ensures adequate sharing of incident information.   The Plant ensures the hazard information available to community emergency responders is accurate.  Important keys to the success of our emergency response program include:

   

A well-trained on-site emergency organization

Emergency-response training for all employees, including routine drills

Critique of drills for continuous improvement.

Active Community Advisory Panel
